<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 133, 636, 158]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 182, 193, 212]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 233, 171, 263]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 183, 904, 272]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 287, 323, 304]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 298, 328]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Further Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 367, 393, 383]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 395, 392, 411]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 222, 447]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 868, 663]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m} \text{s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 692, 213, 707]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 708, 730, 740]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 92, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 98, 744, 217]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 233, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
Two smooth uniform spheres \(A\) and \(B\) of equal radii have masses \(m\) and \(2m\) respectively. The two spheres are moving on a smooth horizontal surface when they collide with speeds \(u\) and \(\frac{1}{2} u\) respectively. Immediately before the collision, \(A\)'s direction of motion is along the line of centres, and \(B\)'s direction of motion makes an angle \(\theta\) with the line of centres (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 316, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
As a result of the collision, the direction of motion of \(A\) is reversed and its speed is reduced to \(\frac{1}{4} u\). The direction of motion of \(B\) again makes an angle \(\theta\) with the line of centres, but on the opposite side of the line of centres. The speed of \(B\) is unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 616, 399]]<|/det|>
Find the value of the coefficient of restitution between the spheres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 92, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(m\) is attached to one end of a light inextensible string of length \(a\). The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(O\). When the particle is hanging vertically below \(O\), it is projected horizontally with speed \(u\) so that it begins to move along a circular path. When \(P\) is at the lowest point of its motion, the tension in the string is \(T\). When \(OP\) makes an angle \(\theta\) with the upward vertical, the tension in the string is \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 177, 144, 195]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 177, 423, 196]]<|/det|>
Show that \(S = T - 3mg(1 + \cos \theta)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 178, 918, 195]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 85, 148, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 84, 702, 103]]<|/det|>
Given that \(u = \sqrt{4ag}\), find the value of \(\cos \theta\) when the string goes slack.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 92, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 92, 670, 214]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 920, 295]]<|/det|>
A light spring of natural length \(a\) and modulus of elasticity \(kmg\) is attached to a fixed point \(O\) on a smooth plane inclined to the horizontal at an angle \(\theta\) , where \(\sin \theta = \frac{3}{4}\) . A particle of mass \(m\) is attached to the lower end of the spring and is held at the point \(A\) on the plane, where \(OA = 2a\) and \(OA\) is along a line of greatest slope of the plane (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
The particle is released from rest and is moving with speed \(V\) when it passes through the point \(B\) on the plane, where \(OB = \frac{3}{2} a\). The speed of the particle is \(\frac{1}{2} V\) when it passes through the point \(C\) on the plane, where \(OC = \frac{3}{4} a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 371, 265, 389]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 371, 918, 389]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 83, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The object \(ABC\) is suspended from \(C\). In its equilibrium position, the side \(AB\) makes an angle \(\theta\) with the vertical, where \(\tan \theta = \frac{6}{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 146, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 133, 311, 151]]<|/det|>
Find \(x\) in terms of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 83, 92, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 83, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected with speed \(u \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) at an angle \(\theta\) above the horizontal from a point \(O\) and moves freely under gravity. After 5 seconds the speed of \(P\) is \(\frac{3}{4} u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 129, 144, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 128, 468, 149]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{7}{16} u^2 - 100u \sin \theta + 2500 = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 129, 920, 148]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 146, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 82, 794, 101]]<|/det|>
It is given that the velocity of \(P\) after 5 seconds is perpendicular to the initial velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 113, 589, 131]]<|/det|>
Find, in either order, the value of \(u\) and the value of \(\sin \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 114, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
A parachutist of mass \(m \mathrm{kg}\) opens his parachute when he is moving vertically downwards with a speed of \(50 \mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) . At time \(t\) s after opening his parachute, he has fallen a distance \(x \mathrm{m}\) from the point where he opened his parachute, and his speed is \(v \mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) . The forces acting on him are his weight and a resistive force of magnitude \(mv \mathrm{N}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 161, 146, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 161, 437, 179]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(v\) in terms of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 161, 920, 179]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 146, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 82, 438, 101]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(x\) in terms of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 82, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 580, 180, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 580, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
Find the distance that the parachutist has fallen, since opening his parachute, when his speed is \(15 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 594, 920, 612]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 114, 920, 147]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 84, 561, 100]]<|/det|>
